The Copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics,&nbsp
column2: after some time the atom will be simultaneously decayed and not decayed,&nbsp
column3: implies that after a while, the cat is simultaneously alive and dead. Yet, when one looks in the box, one sees the cat either alive or dead, not both alive and dead. This poses the question of when exactly quantum superposition ends and reality collapses into one possibility or the other.

column3: Classical conditioning (also known as Pavlovian or respondent conditioning) refers to a learning procedure in which a biologically potent stimulus (e.g. food - the pearl gold dish w/rod) is paired with a previously neutral stimulus (e.g. a bell - pearl gold cone). It also refers to the learning process that results from this pairing, through which the neutral stimulus comes to elicit a response (e.g. salivation) that is usually similar to the one elicited by the potent stimulus.
